As seen in Fig. 1, the introduction ofl-[ring-2H4]Tyr into Rho produces several highly reproducible changes in the region between 1800 and 1000 cm−1. In particular, several bands are altered with a change in intensity, reflecting an isotope-induced shift in frequency, including those near 1595, 1570, 1517, 1423, 1373, 1348, 1275, 1253, 1221 (sh), and 1178 cm−1. There are also bands near 1643 and 1535 cm−1 whose intensities are not reproducible within each set and are therefore not assigned to tyrosine vibrations. This variability is most likely due to sample instability observed in the highly absorbing amide I and II regions as well as small differences in sample preparation which can give rise to polarization effects. In general, the changes we have assigned to tyrosine vibrations can be caused either by an isotope-induced frequency shift of a tyrosine/tyrosinate vibrational mode out of a particular region or by a shift of a labeled tyrosine/tyrosinate mode into that region of the spectrum. Detailed assignments can be made on the basis of comparison with Tyr andl-[ring-2H4]Tyr model compounds. For example, a decrease in intensity at 1595 cm−1 and increase at 1570 cm−1 due tol-[ring-2H4]Tyr incorporation (Fig. 1, inset) agrees well with the isotope induced downshift of the 1598 cm−1 ring stretching mode of tyrosinate to 1569 cm−1 inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr measured at pH 12 (Fig. 2). Similarly, a drop in intensity near 1275 cm−1 and increase near 1253 cm−1 (Fig. 1, inset) (this increase appears as a maximum at 1245 cm−1 in a double difference spectrum; not shown) agrees qualitatively with the isotope-induced shift of a band at 1271 cm−1 in l-tyrosinate to 1238 cm−1 inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr (Fig. 2). Previously this band was assigned to the C–O− stretch mode of tyrosinate (37Rothschild K.J. Roepe P. Ahl P.L. Earnest T.N. Bogomolni R.A. Das Gupta S.K. Mulliken C.M. Herzfeld J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 347-351Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar, 38Hienerwadel R. Boussac A. Breton J. Diner B.A. Berthomieu C. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 14712-14723Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Overall, these data, and in particular the appearance of positive bands characteristic of (labeled) tyrosinate, indicate that a tyrosine residue is partially deprotonated in the Meta II state. This might reflect a partial deprotonation of a tyrosine residue in Rho upon formation of Meta II (see below) or, alternatively, a change in environment of an existing tyrosinate in Rho upon Meta II formation. Additional bands that exhibit reproducible isotope-induced changes are assignable to vibrational modes found in tyrosine orl-[ring-2H4]Tyr. However, the pattern is complex and may reflect one or more tyrosines that undergo a change in environment or protonation state during Meta II formation. For example, the positive 1517-cm−1 band, which drops in intensity, is close to the frequency of an intense tyrosine ring vibration in l-Tyr (37Rothschild K.J. Roepe P. Ahl P.L. Earnest T.N. Bogomolni R.A. Das Gupta S.K. Mulliken C.M. Herzfeld J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1986; 83: 347-351Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar, 39Bendit E.G. Biopolymers. 1967; 5: 525-533Crossref Scopus (30) Google Scholar) and therefore reflects a tyrosine in the Meta II state. Other bands that match known tyrosine frequencies are at 1373 cm−1 (not assigned), 1250 cm−1 (bending mode of tyrosine hydroxyl group), and 1179 cm−1 (ring CH bending mode). The 1373- and 1179-cm−1 bands are positive and therefore most likely reflect tyrosine(s) in Meta II. The 1373-cm−1 band shifts to 1348 cm−1 inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr-Rho in agreement with published spectra (38Hienerwadel R. Boussac A. Breton J. Diner B.A. Berthomieu C. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 14712-14723Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). However, the increased intensity at 1250 cm−1 may reflect a change in a tyrosine residue in the unbleached state of Rho. Part of the intensity changes in this region were already attributed to the downshift of a positive tyrosinate band from 1277 cm−1 to near 1248 cm−1 in the Meta II state (see above). However, a prominent tyrosine mode due to the bending vibration of the tyrosine hydroxyl also occurs at this frequency and downshifts inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr to 1226 cm−1 (38Hienerwadel R. Boussac A. Breton J. Diner B.A. Berthomieu C. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 14712-14723Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar) in good agreement with the change observed at 1221 cm−1 inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr-Rho. This band is not likely to be due to residual Meta I, which exhibits a band near 1215 cm−1 (30DeGrip W.J. Gray D. Gillespie J. Bovee P.H.M. Van den Berg E.M.M. Lugtenburg J. Rothschild K.J. Biochem. 1997; 243: 174-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), because no increase in the corresponding Meta I specific band at 950 cm−1 is observed (not shown). Finally, a prominent drop in intensity at 1423 cm−1 (Fig. 1) inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr-Rho might be due to the isotope-induced downshift of negative tyrosine ring mode from the 1515 cm−1 region. A band due to such a ring mode has been previously identified in thel-[ring-2H4]Tyr-labeled Photosystem II in the TyrD to TyrD* FTIR difference spectrum (38Hienerwadel R. Boussac A. Breton J. Diner B.A. Berthomieu C. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 14712-14723Crossref PubMed Scopus (109) Google Scholar). Alternatively, this change might be due to a mode observed at 1418 cm−1 inl-[ring-2H4]Tyr at high pH, which downshifts from 1498 cm−1 inl-Tyr at high pH (Fig. 2). This would indicate that a (partially) ionized tyrosine exists in Rho. Similar to the results reported above for Rho,l-[ring-2H4]Tyr labeling causes a downshift of a band from 1590 to 1570 cm−1 in the bR difference spectrum (Fig. 3, inset), although the downshifted bands are positive in the Rho spectrum and negative in the bR spectrum. Also, similar to rhodopsin a band at 1276 cm−1 appears to shift to near 1248 cm−1 in the bR → M difference spectrum (Fig. 3, inset). Here again, the frequencies are similar to bands observed in the Rho → Meta II difference spectrum, although the signs of the bands are reversed. In this work, FTIR difference spectroscopy and amino acid isotope labeling were combined for the first time to analyze structural changes of tyrosines in rhodopsin. Isotope labeling was accomplished by growing Sf9 insect cells on a stringent medium containingl-[ring-2H4]Tyr. Tyrosine bands can be identified and assigned on the basis of the isotope induced shifts and by comparison with a series of model tyrosine compounds at high and low pH. Our results clearly demonstrate that a set of bands in the Rho → Meta II difference spectra can be assigned to vibrational modes of tyrosine and tyrosinate. On this basis, it can be concluded that one or more tyrosines participate in the rhodopsin photocascade up to formation of the Meta II intermediate and that at least a partial protonation of a tyrosinate is involved. A possible involvement of tyrosine residues was previously proposed on the basis of UV difference spectroscopy (55Rafferty C.N. Photochem. Photobiol. 1979; 29: 109-120Crossref Scopus (47) Google Scholar) and site-specific mutagenesis (56Nakayama T.A. Khorana H.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4269-4275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and also suggested by a recent study using UV resonance Raman spectroscopy (57Kochendoerfer G.G. Kaminaka S. Mathies R.A. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 13153-13159Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The similarity between the pattern of isotope-induced changes observed in bacteriorhodopsin and rhodopsin is particularly interesting. Earlier studies based on tyrosine isotope labels (41Roepe P. Ahl P.L. Das Gupta S.K. Herzfeld J. Rothschild K.J. Biochemistry. 1987; 26: 6696-6707Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar), site-directed mutagenesis (21Braiman M.S. Mogi T. Stern L.J. Hackett N.R. Chao B.H. Khorana H.G. Rothschild K.J. Proteins Struct. Funct. Genet. 1988; 3: 219-229Crossref PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar), and site-directed isotope labeling (58Liu X.-M. Sonar S. Lee C.-P. Coleman M. RajBhandary U.L. Rothschild K.J. Biophys. Chem. 1995; 56: 63-70Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar) concluded that tyrosine bands identified in the FTIR difference spectra of bacteriorhodopsin arose from protonation changes in Tyr-185 located in the F-helix. Subsequent FTIR measurements on bR containing a13C isotope label in the C1 position of Tyr-185 indicated that the Tyr-185/Pro-186 peptide bond buried in the center of the F-helix undergoes some type of structural rearrangement (59Ludlam C.F.C. Sonar S. Lee C.-P. Coleman M. Herzfeld J. RajBhandary U.L. Rothschild K.J. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 2-6Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). An interesting possibility is that the Tyr-185/Pro-186 bond serves as a hinge, which gives rise to the apparent tilting of the F-helix late in the bR photocycle (60Subramaniam S. Gerstein M. Oesterhelt D. Henderson R. Embo J. 1993; 12: 1-8Crossref PubMed Scopus (362) Google Scholar, 61Vonck J. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 5870-5878Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). The present findings indicate that a similar, although reversed, pattern of tyrosine/tyrosinate changes occurs also upon photoactivation of rhodopsin. Although on the basis of this study we cannot assign these changes to any particular tyrosine(s) in rhodopsin, an interesting candidate is Tyr-268. This residue is also positioned adjacent to a Pro residue (Pro-267). It is well known that Pro residues break α-helical structure and can function as kinks allowing independent movement of adjacent helical segments. The existence of a Tyr/Pro pair in the center of helix 6 in bacteriorhodopsin (Tyr-185, Pro-186) and a Pro/Tyr pair in rhodopsin (Pro-267, Tyr-268) raises the possibility that such a pair acts synergistically independent of the order of these residues, thereby forming a potential hinge for movements in helix 6 in response to chromophore isomerization. Indeed, several lines of evidence have been presented that a rigid body movement involving part of helix 6 takes place during photoactivation of rhodopsin (62Farrens D.L. Altenbach C. Yang K. Hubbell W.L. Khorana H.G. Science. 1996; 274: 768-770Crossref PubMed Scopus (1117) Google Scholar, 63Yang K. Farrens D.L. Hubbell W.L. Khorana H.G. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 12464-12469Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar, 64Shieh T. Han M. Sakmar T.P. Smith S.O. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 269: 373Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar). Also, recent structural models for rhodopsin (e.g. Refs. 64Shieh T. Han M. Sakmar T.P. Smith S.O. J. Mol. Biol. 1997; 269: 373Crossref PubMed Scopus (93) Google Scholar and 65Tang L. Ebrey T. Subramaniam S. Isr. J. Chem. 1995; 35: 193-209Crossref Scopus (24) Google Scholar) place Tyr-268 close to Glu-113, suggesting a possible role in the deprotonation of the Schiff base upon Meta II formation, which could be related to the (partial) protonation indicated by our data. In fact, mutagenesis studies show that replacement of Tyr-268 by Phe perturbs ligand binding and activation of rhodopsin (56Nakayama T.A. Khorana H.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 4269-4275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and that the adjacent Trp-265 also is involved structurally in formation of Meta II (66Ridge K. Bhattacharya S. Nakayama T. Khorana H.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 6770-6775Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 67Lin S.W. Sakmar T.P. Biochemistry. 1996; 35: 11149-11159Crossref PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar). Actually, this region probably is one of the hot spots in rhodopsin activation, because in the vicinity of Tyr-268 are also residues Gly-121 and Phe-261, which form a synergistic functional unit with the 9-methyl group of the chromophore (68Han M. Lin S.W. Minkova M. Smith S.O. Sakmar T.P. Journal of Biological Chemistry. 1996; 271: 32337-32342Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Mutation of these residues in most cases has a profound effect on dark and/or rest activity of rhodopsin (68Han M. Lin S.W. Minkova M. Smith S.O. Sakmar T.P. Journal of Biological Chemistry. 1996; 271: 32337-32342Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar, 69Han M. Lou J. Nakanishi K. Sakmar T.P. Smith S.O. Journal of Biological Chemistry. 1997; 272: 23081-23085Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). However, to definitely identify Tyr-268 as (one of) the residue(s) responsible for the changes we observe additional site-specific mutagenesis and/or site-directed isotope labeling will be required. Because mutagenesis tends to perturb functionally or structurally active sites, site-directed isotope labeling will be the preferred method. Our results suggest a common element for the primary mechanism of rhodopsin and bacteriorhodopsin that goes beyond the general features of a retinylidene chromophore and a seven-helix transmembrane domain. In particular, it establishes that similar tyrosine/tyrosinate changes occur during activation of both proteins. In fact, the reversal of the signs of tyrosine/tyrosinate assigned bands may be related to the respective role of the all-trans chromophore in the activation of the rhodopsin and bacteriorhodopsin systems as indicated by FTIR studies on the effects of removal of the all-transchromophore in rhodopsin (29Rothschild K.J. Gillespie J. DeGrip W.J. Biophys. J. 1987; 51: 345-350Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (50) Google Scholar) and bacteriorhodopsin (25Ludlam G.J. Rothschild K.J. FEBS Lett. 1997; 407: 285-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar). If these similarities arise in changes in the F-helix (helix 6), then it is possible that a common mechanism of chromophore-protein coupling exists in both proteins. This is a very important issue that will be addressed by subsequent studies using a combination of FTIR difference spectroscopy, mutagenesis, and isotope labeling. We thank Shari Beharry and Jerzy Olejnik for technical assistance.

The mesangial cell provides structural support to the kidney glomerulus. A polymerase chain reaction-based cDNA display approach identified a novel protein-tyrosine phosphatase, rPTP-GMC1, whose transcript expression is transiently and dramatically up-regulated during the period of mesangial cell migration and proliferation that follows mesangial cell injury in the anti-Thy 1 model of mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis in the rat.In situ hybridization analysis confirmed that rPTP-GMC1 mRNA is up-regulated specifically by mesangial cells responding to the injury and is not detectable in other cells in the kidney or in many normal tissues. In cell culture, rPTP-GMC1 is expressed by mesangial cells but not by glomerular endothelial or epithelial cells (podocytes). The longest transcript (7.5 kilobases) encodes a receptor-like protein-tyrosine phosphatase consisting of a single catalytic domain, a transmembrane segment, and 18 fibronectin type III-like repeats in the extracellular segment. A splice variant predicts a truncated molecule missing the catalytic domain. rPTP-GMC1 maps to human chromosome 12q15 and to the distal end of mouse chromosome 10. The predicted structure of rPTP-GMC1 and its pattern of expression in vivo and in culture suggest that it plays a role in regulating the adhesion and migration of mesangial cells in response to injury. The mesangial cell provides structural support to the kidney glomerulus. Glomerular disease is initiated by a variety of factors, including immunologic, infectious, and toxic agents, as well as hemodynamic processes. A central pathological feature of many types of acute and progressive glomerular disease is injury of mesangial cells, which respond by proliferating as well as by secreting growth factors and extracellular matrix proteins. This contributes to resolution of glomerular damage but may also lead to fibrosis, which occurs in many chronic disease processes. The glomerular mesangial cell is a mesenchymally derived cell that shares properties with fibroblasts and smooth muscle cells and provides structural support to the glomerular tuft (1Schlondorff D. FASEB J. 1987; 1: 272-281Crossref PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar).Experimental mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis can be induced in rats by the injection of anti-Thy 1 antibody, which binds to the Thy 1 antigen expressed on the rat mesangial cell (2Johnson R.J. Kidney Int. 1994; 45: 1769-1782Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar). Binding of the Thy 1 antibody results in a complement (C5b-9)-dependent killing of mesangial cells (mesangiolysis), which is followed by a transient phase of mesangial cell proliferation (days 2–7) and matrix expansion (days 7–42) resembling mesangial proliferative glomerulonephritis in man (2Johnson R.J. Kidney Int. 1994; 45: 1769-1782Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (220) Google Scholar, 3Alpers C.E. Hudkins K.L. Gown A.M. Johnson R.J. Kidney Int. 1992; 41: 1134-1142Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar). Recently, repopulation of the mesangium in the anti-Thy 1 model has also been shown to involve migration of surviving mesangial cells (days 2–5) from the hilus to the periphery of the glomerulus (5Hugo C. Nature. 1990; 346: 371-374Crossref PubMed Scopus (930) Google Scholar) play major roles in the mesangial cell proliferative response and extracellular matrix expansion in experimental glomerulonephritis. Despite the evident role of protein tyrosine phosphorylation in processes activated by growth factor receptors with protein-tyrosine kinase activity, little information regarding the expression and biological roles of protein-tyrosine phosphatases (PTPase)1 in glomerular disease has been reported. The potential importance of PTPases in the glomerulus has been underscored by the recent identification of GLEPP1, a type III receptor-like PTPase (rPTPase), which is localized to the specialized foot processes of the podocyte (11Thomas P.E. Wharram B.L. Goyal M. Wiggins J.E. Holzman L.B. Wiggins R.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 19953-19962Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 12Wiggins R.C. Wiggins J.E. Goyal M. Wharram B.L. Thomas P.E. Genomics. 1995; 27: 174-181Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar). GLEPP1 has been proposed to play a role in the regulation of podocyte foot process structure and function. In support of this hypothesis, GLEPP1 protein levels are reduced in several types of human glomerular disease and in several animal models of glomerulonephritis (13Yang D.H. Goyal M. Sharif K. Kershaw D. Thomas P. Dysko R. Wiggins R. Lab. Invest. 1996; 74: 571-584PubMed Google Scholar).To identify PTPases as potential mediators of the mesangial cell response in glomerular disease, we have evaluated PTPases expressed in the rat anti-Thy 1 model. This report describes the identification, molecular cloning, and characterization of rPTP-GMC1, a new receptor PTPase expressed by glomerular mesangial cells. Our results demonstrate that rPTP-GMC1 is highly restricted to the mesangial cell and that expression is acutely up-regulated in actively proliferating and migrating mesangial cells in the anti-Thy 1 model. rPTP-GMC1 is similar in structure to GLEPP1 and may sense or regulate cell-cell or cell-matrix interactions to mediate glomerular repair.DISCUSSIONMany types of human renal disease, such as diabetic nephropathy, acute glomerulonephritis, IgA nephropathy, and acute lupus nephritis, share similarities with the anti-Thy 1 glomerulonephritis model. Loss of mesangial cells results in dissolution of the glomerular architecture, which stimulates a response to injury mediated by repopulating mesangial cells (3Alpers C.E. Hudkins K.L. Gown A.M. Johnson R.J. Kidney Int. 1992; 41: 1134-1142Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (257) Google Scholar, 38Morita T. Churg J. Invest. 1991; 87: 847-858Crossref PubMed Scopus (431) Google Scholar).We have cloned and characterized a new type III receptor protein-tyrosine phosphatase in experimental glomerulonephritis. rPTP-GMC1 exhibits a striking pattern of expression which is tightly coupled to the kinetics of the migrating mesangial cell in the rat anti-Thy 1 model. Following the acute mesangiolysis, the first identifiable mesangial cells consistently originate from the glomerular hilus or extraglomerular mesangium (5Hugo C. Shankland S.J. Bowen-Pope D.F. Couser W.G. Johnson R.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1997; 100: 786-794Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). These actively proliferating cells dramatically up-regulate expression of rPTP-GMC1. From 36 h to 7 days after disease induction, the responding mesangial cells participate in a coordinated wave of proliferation and migration which distributes them throughout the glomerulus (5Hugo C. Shankland S.J. Bowen-Pope D.F. Couser W.G. Johnson R.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1997; 100: 786-794Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). By day 7, the proliferative/migratory phase is essentially complete and this is coincident with loss of rPTP-GMC1 expression.A role for rPTP-GMC1 is supported by genetic studies, which have provided good evidence for receptor PTPases as important regulators of cell migration and axon guidance. For example, fourDrosophila rPTPases (DLAR, DPTP10D, DPTP69D, and DPTP99A) are expressed specifically in the nervous system in overlapping subsets of neurons and play important roles in growth cone guidance and target innervation (42Zinn K. Semin. Cell Biol. 1993; 4: 397-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). Drosophila DPTP69D null mutants express motor neuron growth cones that do not target properly and either overshoot their muscle targets or stop prematurely (43Desai C.J. Krueger N.X. Saito H. Zinn K. Development. 1997; 124: 1941-1952Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Mutants in DLAR result in motor axons that fail to reach their targets due to improper directional decisions at key checkpoints (44Krueger N.X. Van Vactor D. Wan H.I. Gelbart W.M. Goodman C.S. Saito H. Cell. 1996; 84: 611-622Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar).Migrating cells interact with the extracellular matrix via focal adhesions (FA), which are contact points that link actin stress fibers to the membrane cytoskeleton and to transmembrane integrins (45Burridge K. Fath K. Kelly T. Nuckolls G. Turner C. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1988; 4: 487-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (1689) Google Scholar). It is well established that protein tyrosine phosphorylation plays a key role in regulating these structures. Engagement of integrins by the extracellular matrix in migrating cells induces tyrosine phosphorylation of several FA components including pp125FAKand paxillin (46Burridge K. Turner C.E. Romer L.H. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 893-903Crossref PubMed Scopus (1175) Google Scholar). Specific PTPases have been linked to FA phosphorylation. For example LAR, a broadly expressed receptor PTPase, localizes to FAs in migrating cells but seems to be excluded from developing FAs at extending lamellopodia (47Serra Pages C. Kedersha N.L. Fazikas L. Medley Q. Debant A. Streuli M. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 2827-2838Crossref PubMed Scopus (290) Google Scholar). This is consistent with a role of this receptor PTPase in FA disassembly by serving to dephosphorylate components that were activated initially by phosphorylation.Mesangial cells in culture migrate toward a variety of factors including platelet-derived growth factor, fibronectin, and thrombospondin, which may also be important stimulators of mesangial cell migration in the Thy 1 model (4Barnes J.L. Hastings R.R. De la Garza M.A. Am. J. Pathol. 1994; 145: 585-597PubMed Google Scholar, 48Taraboletti G. Morigi M. Figliuzzi M. Giavazzi R. Zoja C. Remuzzi G. Lab. Invest. 1992; 67: 566-571PubMed Google Scholar, 49Barnes J.L. Hevey K.A. Lab. Invest. 1990; 62: 379-382PubMed Google Scholar). Our results suggest that rPTP-GMC1 may play a role in cell migration by either regulating the formation of cell-cell or cell-matrix adhesion sites or providing a pathfinding or context-recognition function that targets the mesangial cell to its correct association with other glomerular cells. The loss of rPTP-GMC1 expression, concurrent with the end of the proliferative/migratory phase in the Thy 1 model, suggests that it plays a dynamic, rather than constitutive, role in formation of glomerular structure. A role for rPTP-GMC1 is supported by genetic studies, which have provided good evidence for receptor PTPases as important regulators of cell migration and axon guidance. For example, fourDrosophila rPTPases (DLAR, DPTP10D, DPTP69D, and DPTP99A) are expressed specifically in the nervous system in overlapping subsets of neurons and play important roles in growth cone guidance and target innervation (42Zinn K. Semin. Cell Biol. 1993; 4: 397-402Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). Drosophila DPTP69D null mutants express motor neuron growth cones that do not target properly and either overshoot their muscle targets or stop prematurely (43Desai C.J. Krueger N.X. Saito H. Zinn K. Development. 1997; 124: 1941-1952Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Mutants in DLAR result in motor axons that fail to reach their targets due to improper directional decisions at key checkpoints (44Krueger N.X. Van Vactor D. Wan H.I. Gelbart W.M. Goodman C.S. Saito H. Cell. 1996; 84: 611-622Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar). Migrating cells interact with the extracellular matrix via focal adhesions (FA), which are contact points that link actin stress fibers to the membrane cytoskeleton and to transmembrane integrins (45Burridge K. Fath K. Kelly T. Nuckolls G. Turner C. Annu. Rev. Cell Biol. 1988; 4: 487-525Crossref PubMed Scopus (1689) Google Scholar). It is well established that protein tyrosine phosphorylation plays a key role in regulating these structures. Engagement of integrins by the extracellular matrix in migrating cells induces tyrosine phosphorylation of several FA components including pp125FAKand paxillin (46Burridge K. Turner C.E. Romer L.H. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119: 893-903Crossref PubMed Scopus (1175) Google Scholar). Specific PTPases have been linked to FA phosphorylation. For example LAR, a broadly expressed receptor PTPase, localizes to FAs in migrating cells but seems to be excluded from developing FAs at extending lamellopodia (47Serra Pages C. Kedersha N.L. Fazikas L. Medley Q. Debant A. Streuli M. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 2827-2838Crossref PubMed Scopus (290) Google Scholar). This is consistent with a role of this receptor PTPase in FA disassembly by serving to dephosphorylate components that were activated initially by phosphorylation. Mesangial cells in culture migrate toward a variety of factors including platelet-derived growth factor, fibronectin, and thrombospondin, which may also be important stimulators of mesangial cell migration in the Thy 1 model (4Barnes J.L. Hastings R.R. De la Garza M.A. Am. J. Pathol. 1994; 145: 585-597PubMed Google Scholar, 48Taraboletti G. Morigi M. Figliuzzi M. Giavazzi R. Zoja C. Remuzzi G. Lab. Invest. 1992; 67: 566-571PubMed Google Scholar, 49Barnes J.L. Hevey K.A. Lab. Invest. 1990; 62: 379-382PubMed Google Scholar). Our results suggest that rPTP-GMC1 may play a role in cell migration by either regulating the formation of cell-cell or cell-matrix adhesion sites or providing a pathfinding or context-recognition function that targets the mesangial cell to its correct association with other glomerular cells. The loss of rPTP-GMC1 expression, concurrent with the end of the proliferative/migratory phase in the Thy 1 model, suggests that it plays a dynamic, rather than constitutive, role in formation of glomerular structure. We are grateful to Dr. Rick Johnson for providing the anti-Thy 1 antibody, cell lines, advice, and support. We thank Joyce Murphy and Jeff Pippen for excellent technical assistance. We thank Dr. Stephen Adler for providing the glomerular endothelial cell line. We also thank Patricia Moesner and Kumar Narayanan in our department and Lucy Rowe at the Jackson Laboratory for help with the mouse mapping. Our appreciation is also extended to Sushma Thomas for the FISH mapping.

Although it is known that lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a)) binds to proteoglycans, the mechanism for this binding has not been fully elucidated. In order to shed light on this subject, we examined the interactions of decorin, a proteoglycan with a well defined protein core and a single glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chain, with Lp(a) and derivatives, namely Lp(a) deprived of apo(a), or Lp(a−), free apo(a), and the two main proteolytic fragments, F1 and F2. By circular dichroism criteria, the decorin preparations used had the same secondary structure as that previously reported for native decorin. Authentic low density lipoprotein from the same human donor was used as a control. In a solid phase system, Lp(a−)and low density lipoprotein bound to decorin in a comparable manner. This binding required Ca2+/Mg2+ ions, was lysine-mediated, and was markedly decreased in the presence of GAG-depleted decorin, suggesting the ionic nature of the interaction likely involving apoB100 and the GAG component of decorin. Free apo(a) also bound to decorin; however, the binding was neither cation-dependent nor lysine-mediated, unaffected by sialic acid depletion of apo(a), and markedly decreased when either reduced and alkylated apo(a) or reduced and alkylated decorin was used in the assay. Of note, the binding of apo(a) was unaffected when it was incubated with a spectrally native decorin that had been renatured from either 4 m guanidine hydrochloride by extensive dialysis or cooled from 65 to 25 °C. On the other hand, the binding significantly increased when decorin was depleted of GAGs, which by themselves had no affinity for apo(a). The binding of apo(a) to the decorin protein core was also elicited by the C-terminal domain of apo(a), and it was favored by high NaCl concentrations, 1 to 2m. No binding was exhibited by the N-terminal domain accounting for the lack of effect of apo(a) size polymorphism on the binding. In the case of whole Lp(a), the binding to immobilized decorin was mostly GAG-dependent and ionic in nature. A minor contribution by apo(a) was detected when GAG-depleted decorin was used in the assay. Our results indicate that the binding of Lp(a) to decorin involves interactions both electrostatic (apoB100-GAG) and hydrophobic (apo(a)-decorin protein core), and that the binding of apo(a) requires decorin protein core to be in its native state. Lipoprotein(a) (Lp(a))1is a highly atherogenic lipoprotein having as a protein moiety apoB100 disulfide linked to apolipoprotein(a) (apo(a)) (1Lawn R.M. Scanu A.M. Fuster V. Ross R. Topol E. Atherosclerosis and Coronary Artery Disease. Lippincott-Raven, Philadelphia1996: 151-161Google Scholar). Apo(a) comprises a multi-kringle structure and a protease domain both of which are highly homologous to the corresponding structures of plasminogen (2McLean J.W. Tomlinson J.E. Kuang W. Eaton D.L. Chen E.Y. Fless G.M. Scanu A.M. Lawn R.M. Nature. 1987; 330: 132-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (1597) Google Scholar). Based on this homology, the apo(a) kringles have been classified into two major classes, IV and V. There are 10 subclasses of kringle IV, numbered from 1 to 10, exhibiting some differences in amino acid composition (3Scanu A.M. Edelstein C. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1995; 1256: 1-12Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). All of these kringles occur as a single copy except for kringle IV-2 whose number varies among individuals and accounts for the size polymorphism of apo(a) (4Lackner C. Cohen J.C. Hobbs H.H. Hum. Mol. Genet. 1993; 2: 933-940Crossref PubMed Scopus (315) Google Scholar, 5Van der Hoek Y.Y. Wittekoek M.E. Beisiegel U. Kastelein J.J. Koschinsky M.L. Hum. Mol. Genet. 1993; 2: 361-366Crossref PubMed Scopus (174) Google Scholar, 6Marcovina S.M. Zhang Z.H. Gaur V.P. Albers J.J. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1993; 191: 1192-1196Crossref PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar). In turn, only one copy of kringle V has been reported (2McLean J.W. Tomlinson J.E. Kuang W. Eaton D.L. Chen E.Y. Fless G.M. Scanu A.M. Lawn R.M. Nature. 1987; 330: 132-137Crossref PubMed Scopus (1597) Google Scholar). Proteoglycans (PGs) are important structural components of the extracellular matrix of the vessel wall. They consist of glycosaminoglycan (GAG) chain(s) covalently attached to a protein core (7Wight T.N. Fuster V. Ross R. Topol E. Atherosclerosis and Coronary Artery Disease. Lippincott-Raven, Philadelphia1996: 421-440Google Scholar). PGs are structurally diverse due to the differences in core proteins and the number, size, and monosaccaride sequence of the GAG chains (7Wight T.N. Fuster V. Ross R. Topol E. Atherosclerosis and Coronary Artery Disease. Lippincott-Raven, Philadelphia1996: 421-440Google Scholar). Lp(a) has been shown to bind in vitro to free GAGs (8Dahlén G. Ericson C. Berg K. Clin. Genet. 1978; 14: 36-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 9Bihari-Varga M. Gruber E. Rotheneder M. Zechner R. Kostner G.M. Arteriosclerosis. 1988; 8: 851-857Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and mixed aortic PG (9Bihari-Varga M. Gruber E. Rotheneder M. Zechner R. Kostner G.M. Arteriosclerosis. 1988; 8: 851-857Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). However, little is known about the mechanism of this binding. It has been proposed that apoB100 of Lp(a) interacts ionically with the GAG component of PGs (8Dahlén G. Ericson C. Berg K. Clin. Genet. 1978; 14: 36-42Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 9Bihari-Varga M. Gruber E. Rotheneder M. Zechner R. Kostner G.M. Arteriosclerosis. 1988; 8: 851-857Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). On the other hand, the binding of apo(a) to PG has been considered to be negligible based on the observation by Bihari-Varga et al. (9Bihari-Varga M. Gruber E. Rotheneder M. Zechner R. Kostner G.M. Arteriosclerosis. 1988; 8: 851-857Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) that apo(a) separated from parental Lp(a) under strong reductive conditions failed to form a visible complex when interacted with free GAGs. We have recently shown (10Edelstein C. Mandala M. Pfaffinger D. Scanu A.M. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 16483-16492Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar) that a functional free apo(a) can be isolated from the parent Lp(a) under mild reductive conditions. This free apo(a) is functional based on its capacity to bind to LDL to form an authentic Lp(a) particle and to bind in vitro to the extracellular matrix proteins such as fibrinogen (11Klezovitch O. Edelstein C. Scanu A.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1996; 98: 185-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and fibronectin (12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). In addition, we also have shown that enzymes of the elastase family cleave human apo(a) in vitro into two main fragments, F1 and F2, representing the C- and N-terminal domains, respectively, which can be easily separated from each other by lysine-Sepharose chromatography (12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The availability of free apo(a) and derivatives prompted us to investigate whether apo(a), either free or as a constitutive component of Lp(a), binds to PG and, if so, to attempt to define the basis for this interaction. For this purpose, as a model system, we studied the binding of Lp(a) and its derivatives, apo(a) and apo(a)-free Lp(a) (Lp(a−)), to decorin. Decorin represents a well characterized PG having a 36-kDa protein core of known structure and a single GAG chain, predominantly dermatan sulfate (DS) (13Kresse H. Hausser H. Schonherr E. Bittner K. Eur. J. Clin. Chem. Clin. Biochem. 1994; 32: 259-264PubMed Google Scholar). This PG is synthesized by vascular endothelial and smooth muscle cells (14Asundi V.K. Dreher K.L. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 59: 314-321PubMed Google Scholar, 15Järveläinen H.T. Kinsella M.G. Wight T.N. Sandell L.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 266: 23274-23281Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 16Järveläinen H.T. Iruela-Arispe M.L. Kinsella M.G. Sandell L.J. Sage E.H. Wight T.N. Exp. Cell Res. 1992; 203: 395-401Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar) and is shown to co-localize with collagen type I in primary atherosclerotic plaques (17Riessen R. Isner J.M. Blessing E. Loushin C. Nikol S. Wight T.N. Am. J. Pathol. 1994; 144: 962-974PubMed Google Scholar). Decorin and, particularly, the decorin protein core has a number of important functions including organization of collagen fibrillogenesis, regulation of cell-matrix interaction, and modulation of cell growth via binding to fibronectin, thrombospondin, and transforming growth factor-β (13Kresse H. Hausser H. Schonherr E. Bittner K. Eur. J. Clin. Chem. Clin. Biochem. 1994; 32: 259-264PubMed Google Scholar, 18Iozzo R.V. Crit. Rev. Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1997; 32: 141-174Crossref PubMed Scopus (454) Google Scholar). Moreover, it has been recently demonstrated that the decorin protein core suppresses cell growth by activation of the inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinase, p21 (19De Luca A. Santra M. Baldi A. Giordano A. Iozzo R.V. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 18961-18965Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (226) Google Scholar, 20Santra M. Mann D.M. Mercer E.W. Skorski T. Calabretta B. Iozzo R.V. J. Clin. Invest. 1997; 100: 149-157Crossref PubMed Scopus (184) Google Scholar, 21Moscatello D.K. Santra M. Mann D.M. McQuillan D.J. Wong A.J. Iozzo R.V. J. Clin. Invest. 1998; 101: 406-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (245) Google Scholar). In order to evaluate the role of the decorin protein core in the binding to Lp(a) and its derivatives, we utilized both untreated and GAG-depleted (GD) decorin prepared by treating the latter with chondroitinase ABC (cABC). The secondary structure of the decorin preparations was examined by circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopy. A preliminary account of this work has appeared (22Klezovitch, O., Edelstein, C., and Scanu, A. M. (1997)Circulation 96, (suppl.) I-112Google Scholar). Decorin, extracted from bovine articular cartilage with 4m guanidine hydrochloride (GdnHCl) and purified essentially as described by Rosenberg et al. (23Rosenberg L.C. Choi H.U. Tang L.-H. Johnson T.L. Pal S. Webber C. Reiner A. Poole A.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 6304-6313Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), was obtained from Sigma in a GdnHCl-free lyophilized form (lot 127H4081). We used decorin from cartilage source as a prototype of decorin since it has been previously shown that the protein structure of this PG is similar irrespective of tissue source as assessed by N-terminal sequencing (24Day A.A. McQuillan C.I. Termine J.D. Young M.R. Biochem. J. 1987; 248: 801-805Crossref PubMed Scopus (98) Google Scholar, 25Choi H.U. Johnson T.L. Pal S. Tang L.-H. Rosenberg L.C. Neame P.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 2876-2884Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 26Roughley P.J. White R.J. Biochem J. 1989; 262: 823-827Crossref PubMed Scopus (81) Google Scholar) and mRNA analyses (27Pulkkinen L. Alitalo T. Krusius T. Peltonen L. Cytogenet. Cell Genet. 1992; 60: 107-111Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar), although it may differ in its GAG side chain. ε-Aminocaproic acid (EACA), l-lysine, bovine serum albumin (BSA), DS, chondroitin 4-sulfate (C4S), phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, diisopropyl fluorophosphate, EDTA, dithioerythritol (DTE), dithiothreitol, 2-mercaptoethanol, SDS, Tween 20, iodoacetamide, porcine pancreatic elastase (EC 3.4.21.36), goat anti-rabbit and anti-mouse IgG alkaline phosphatase conjugates, and ρ-nitrophenyl phosphate were purchased from Sigma. Kallikrein inactivator (KI) was purchased from Calbiochem. Monoclonal anti-decorin protein core antibody and cABC (EC 4.2.2.4) were from Seikagaku Co., Tokyo, Japan. Peptide:N-glycosidase F and N-acetylneuraminidase II were from Glyko Inc., Novato, CA. Rabbit affinity purified antibodies to Lp(a), apo(a), and LDL were prepared as described previously (28Fless G.M. Snyder M.L. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1989; 30: 651-662Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Anti-Lp(a) and anti-apo(a) did not react against LDL and plasminogen, and anti-LDL was unreactive to apo(a). The subjects used for the preparation of Lp(a) and LDL were 4 healthy donors with plasma Lp(a) protein levels in the range of 15–43 mg/dl with a known apo(a) phenotype and genotype. Their plasma was obtained by plasmapheresis performed in the Blood Bank at the University of Chicago. The steps for Lp(a) and LDL isolation were carried out immediately after blood drawing using the procedure outlined below. All of the subjects used in the study gave a written informed consent. Apo(a) phenotyping was performed on isolated apo(a) samples by SDS-PAGE followed by immunoblotting using anti-Lp(a) (10Edelstein C. Mandala M. Pfaffinger D. Scanu A.M. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 16483-16492Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). The mobility of the individual apo(a) bands was compared with isolated apo(a) isoforms of known molecular weights (29Fless G.M. Snyder M.L. Furbee J.W.J. Garcia-Hedo M.T. Mora R. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 13492-13501Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). For apo(a) genotyping, DNA plugs were prepared from blood mononuclear cells, subsequently fractionated by pulsed field gel electrophoresis, and the blots developed with an apo(a)-specific probe essentially as described earlier (30Lackner C. Boerwinkle E. Leffert C.C. Rahmig T. Hobbs H.H. J. Clin. Invest. 1991; 87: 2153-2161Crossref PubMed Scopus (359) Google Scholar). The Lp(a) species used in this study had a single apo(a) isoform. The isoforms examined were between 289 and 488 kDa. To prevent lipoprotein degradation, the plasma obtained by plasmapheresis was adjusted with 0.15% EDTA, 0.01% NaN3,10,000 units/liter KI, and 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Lp(a) was isolated by sequential ultracentrifugation and lysine-Sepharose chromatography as described previously (29Fless G.M. Snyder M.L. Furbee J.W.J. Garcia-Hedo M.T. Mora R. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 13492-13501Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). The purity of the product was assessed by electrophoresis on precast 1% agarose gels (Ciba-Corning, Palo Alto, CA) and Western blots of SDS-PAGE, utilizing anti-Lp(a) and anti-apoB100. The LDL preparations used in this study were isolated at d = 1.030–1.050 g/ml by sequential flotation as described previously (31Schumaker V.N. Puppione D.L. Methods Enzymol. 1986; 128: 155-170Crossref PubMed Scopus (467) Google Scholar) and were assessed to have no apo(a) by electrophoresis and Western blot criteria. Apo(a) was isolated from Lp(a) essentially as described by Edelstein et al. (10Edelstein C. Mandala M. Pfaffinger D. Scanu A.M. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 16483-16492Crossref PubMed Scopus (42) Google Scholar). Briefly, Lp(a), 1 mg/ml protein, was incubated with DTE at a final concentration of 1.5–2 mm. EACA to a final concentration of 100 mm was then added, and the mixture was incubated at room temperature for 1 h under nitrogen gas. After dialysis against 10 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.4, containing 100 mm EACA, 1 mmEDTA, and 0.02% sodium azide, an equal volume of 60% sucrose in the same buffer was added, and the resulting mixture was placed into a TLA 100.3 titanium rotor and spun in a table top TL100 ultracentrifuge at 10 °C, 412,160 × g for 18 h. After centrifugation, the top 0.5-ml fraction contained LDL free of apo(a), Lp(a−). The bottom 1.0-ml fraction contained free apo(a) in pure form. The latter was stored in 10 mm phosphate buffer containing 1 mm EDTA, 0.02% sodium azide, and 125 mmtrehalose at −80 °C. Apo(a) in 50 mm Tris-HCl, 100 mm NaCl, pH 8.0, KI (200 units/ml) was digested with porcine pancreatic elastase at a molar ratio of 25:1 (protein:enzyme) at 22 °C for 2 h, and the reaction was terminated by the addition of 5 mmdiisopropyl fluorophosphate with further incubation for 20 min (12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The digest was applied to a lysine-Sepharose affinity column which was then washed with 3 column volumes of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), 500 mm NaCl, and 200 mm EACA (12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Fragment F1 eluted with PBS and F2 with EACA. The PBS and EACA fractions containing these fragments were each pooled, dialyzed against 10 mmphosphate buffer, pH 7.4, containing 1 mm EDTA, 0.02% sodium azide and concentrated using Centriprep membranes (Amicon Corp., Beverly, MA). The purity of the products was monitored by immunoblot electrophoretic analysis on 4–12% SDS-PAGE (Novex, San Diego, CA) probed with anti-apo(a) (12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Lyophilized apo(a) (289-kDa isoform), 100-μg aliquot, was dissolved in 0.5 ml of 0.1m Tris-Cl, pH 8.0, containing 6 m GdnHCl. For the reduction, dithiothreitol was added to give a 10-fold molar excess over expected disulfides, and the solution was flushed with nitrogen and incubated for 1 h at 37 °C. For alkylation, iodoacetamide was added to give a 5-fold molar excess of reagent over total thiols. The solution was again flushed with nitrogen and incubated for 1 h at 37 °C in the dark. Following the incubation, a 10-fold excess of 2-mercaptoethanol relative to the alkylating agent was added, and the solution was desalted by exhaustive dialysis against 20,000 volumes of 10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 20 mm NaCl for 48 h at 4 °C. Apo(a), 20-μg aliquot, was treated with 10 milliunits of N-acetylneuraminidase II for 3 h at 37 °C according to the manufacturer's instructions. The change in mobility of apo(a) upon removal of sialic acid was monitored by electrophoresis on precast 1% agarose gels (Ciba-Corning, Palo Alto, CA) following by immunoblotting with an anti-apo(a) antibody as described (12Edelstein C. Italia J.A. Klezovitch O. Scanu A.M. J. Lipid Res. 1996; 37: 1786-1801Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) (Fig. 1). For this purpose, 100 μg of decorin protein were incubated with cABC in 100 μl of TBS (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 0.15m NaCl) supplemented with 0.5 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride and 10 units/ml kallikrein inactivator as a function of enzyme concentration (0–10 milliunits), time (0–2 h), and temperature (22–37 °C). The reaction was terminated by adding 1 mm ZnCl2. The level of digestion was assessed by 4–12% SDS-PAGE (Novex, San Diego, CA). Treatment of decorin with cABC generated a product that migrated as a doublet with an estimated mass of 46 and 48 kDa (Fig. 2,lanes 4 and 5). The doublet represented two different N-glycosylated forms of decorin protein core, based on the fact that further digestion with 2.5 milliunits of peptide:N-glycosidase F for 3 h at 37 °C, using the manufacturer's instructions, reduced the protein size to 38 kDa (Fig. 2, lane 6). The cABC-modified doublet product is referred to as GAG-depleted decorin or GD decorin. Neither increase of the amount of cABC to 100 milliunits nor prolonged overnight incubation at 37 °C resulted in further changes in the mobility of GD decorin. There were no apparent changes in electrophoretic mobility of either Lp(a) or apo(a) when treated with cABC. As a result, the following conditions were chosen for the routine preparation of GD decorin: 100 μg of decorin/10 milliunits cABC for 2 h at 37 °C. GD decorin was dialyzed against 20,000 volumes of 1 mmNH4HCO3 for 48 h at 4 °C and subsequently lyophilized. The lyophilized product was kept at −20 °C until use. Lyophilized aliquots, 250 μg each, of decorin and GD decorin, were dissolved in 0.5 ml of 0.1 m Tris-Cl, pH 8.0, containing 6 m GdnHCl. Each sample was reduced and alkylated following the conditions described above for apo(a), and the final products were then dialyzed against 20,000 volumes of 10 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.5, for 48 h at 4 °C. Lyophilized samples of either decorin or GD decorin were dissolved in 10 mmphosphate buffer, pH 7.5, containing 4 m GdnHCl, to reach a protein concentration of 0.25 mg/ml, incubated for 1 h at 25 °C, and used for CD spectroscopy as described below. Another aliquot was subjected to exhaustive dialysis against 20,000 volumes of 10 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.5, for 48 h at 4 °C to remove GdnHCl, equilibrated for 1 h at 25 °C, and subsequently used for CD spectroscopy and binding studies. Lyophilized samples of either decorin or GD decorin were dissolved in 10 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.5, at a protein concentration of 0.11 mg/ml. Each sample was incubated at 65 °C for 1 h, and the CD spectra of the heated products were recorded at 65 °C. Thereafter, the samples were cooled to 25 °C, kept at that temperature for 1 h, and then analyzed by CD spectroscopy and apo(a) binding. The CD spectra of native and modified forms of decorin and GD decorin in 10 mm phosphate buffer, pH 7.5, were recorded in a 1-mm path length cell on an Aviv model 62DS spectropolarimeter equipped with a temperature control unit (Aviv Associates, Inc., Lakewood, NJ). The studies were carried out at 25 °C unless specified. All the recorded spectra were the average of 4 scans and were corrected for background. The mean residue ellipticity was calculated as described (32Adler A.J. Greenfield N.J. Fasman G.D. Methods Enzymol. 1973; 27: 675-735Crossref PubMed Scopus (565) Google Scholar). The percent secondary structure was calculated using a program provided by Aviv Inc. for Aviv CD data sets based on an algorithm of Chang et al. (33Chang C.T. Wu C.S. Yang J.T. Anal. Biochem. 1978; 91: 12-31Crossref Scopus (1026) Google Scholar). Microtiter plates (Beckman Instruments, Fullerton, CA) were coated with 100 μl of 10 μg/ml in TBS of decorin or GD decorin, either native or modified, for 2 h at 37 °C. Edelstein C. Scanu A.M. J. Clin. Invest. 1996; 98: 185-191Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). After three washes with TBST (TBS supplemented with 0.1% BSA and 0.02% Tween 20), various concentrations of either of the following Lp(a), apo(a), apo(a) fragments, LDL, or Lp(a−) were added to the wells in the reaction buffer (10 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, 20 mm NaCl, 2 mm CaCl2, 2 mm MgCl2) and incubated for 1 h at 37 °C. After incubation, the wells were washed three times with TBST which contains 150 mmNaCl. Biochem. 1990; 184: 388-394Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). The bound protein was detected by using either an anti-LDL or an anti-apo(a) antibody in TBST for 1 h at room temperature. At this time, the wells were washed three times with TBST, and the goat anti-rabbit IgG alkaline phosphatase conjugate in TBST was added for 1 h at room temperature. After washing with TBST, ρ-nitrophenyl phosphate (1 mg/ml in diethanolamine buffer, pH 9.8) was added and the color development followed at 405 nm on a microtiter reader, Biomek 100 (Beckman Instruments, Fullerton, CA). Absorbance data were then transformed into moles by using standard curves established for each ligand. Scatchard analysis was carried out by plotting the amount of ligand bound (x axis)versus the ratio of bound to free ligand (yaxis). The B max was obtained from thex intercept, and K d was the ratio of theB max divided by the y intercept. The amount of protein bound was expressed as percentage of that bound in the absence of the effector. As shown in Fig. 3 A, the spectrum of decorin rehydrated from the lyophilized powder in 10 mm phosphate buffer exhibited a symmetrical negative trough with a minimum at 215 nm. The calculated secondary structure gave 45% β-sheet, 15% β-turn, 8% α-helix, and 31% random coil. This secondary structure was abrogated by 4 m GdnHCl and was fully restored after removal of this chaotropic agent by dialysis. The spectrum of reduced and alkylated decorin exhibited a blue shift of the minimum to around 208 nm indicative of an increase in random structure (Fig. 3 A). A marked shift of the minimum to 205 nm was also exhibited by decorin heated at 65 °C; the native spectrum was fully restored upon cooling the sample to 25 °C (Fig. 3 B). The spectrum of GD decorin was similar to that of decorin except for an approximate 20% decrease in the molar ellipticity at 215 nm (Fig. 3 C) representing 40% β-sheet, 7% β-turn, 20% α-helix, and 23% random coil. These data indicated that the removal of GAG, by itself optically inactive (data not shown), caused a structural change favoring an α-helix conformation. Changes in the spectral behavior of GD decorin in 4 m GdnHCl, after reduction and alkylation (Fig. 3 C) and at 65 °C (Fig. 3 D), resembled those of decorin. Apo(a) exhibited concentration-dependent saturable binding to both decorin and GD decorin (Fig. 4 A). The kinetics of adenosine triphosphate (ATP)-dependent proton transport into clathrin-coated vesicles from bovine brain have been studied. We observe that the vacuolar proton-translocating ATPase (V-ATPase) from clathrin-coated vesicles is subject to two different types of inhibition by ADP. The first is competitive inhibition with respect to ATP, with aK i for ADP of 11 μm. The second type of inhibition occurs after preincubation of the V-ATPase in the presence of ADP and Mg2+, which results in inhibition of the initial rate of proton transport followed by reactivation over the course of several minutes. The second effect is observed at ADP concentrations as low as 0.1–0.2 μm, indicating that a high affinity inhibitory complex is formed between ADP and the V-ATPase and is only slowly dissociated after the addition of ATP.We have further investigated the effect of sodium azide, an inhibitor of the F-ATPases that has been shown to stabilize an inactive complex between ADP and the F1-F0-ATP synthase (F-ATPase). We observed that azide inhibited ATP-dependent proton transport by the purified, reconstituted V-ATPase with aK 0.5 of 0.2–0.4 mm but had no effect on ATP hydrolysis. Azide was shown not to increase the passive proton permeability of reconstituted vesicles and did not stimulate ATP hydrolysis by the reconstituted enzyme, in contrast with CCCP, which both abolished the proton gradient and stimulated hydrolysis. Thus, azide does not appear to act as a simple uncoupler of proton transport and ATP hydrolysis. Rather, azide may have some more direct effect on V-ATPase activity. Possible mechanisms by which azide could exert this effect on the V-ATPase and the contrasting effects of azide on the F- and V-ATPases are discussed. The vacuolar (H+)-ATPases (or V-ATPases)1 acidify intracellular compartments in eukaryotic cells and therefore play a crucial role in a variety of cellular processes (1Stevens T.H. Forgac M. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1997; 13: 779-808Crossref PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 2Bowman B.J. Vazquez-Laslop N. Bowman E.J. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 361-370Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 3Kibak H. Taiz L. Starke T. Bernasconi P. Gogarten J.P. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 415-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 407-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 5Anraku Y. Umemoto N. Hirata R. Ohya Y. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 395-405Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 6Kane P.M. Stevens T.H. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 383-394Crossref Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 7Sze H. Ward J.M. Lai S. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 371-382Crossref Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 8Gluck S.L. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 351-360Crossref Scopus (53) Google Scholar). V-ATPases are composed of two functional domains: the peripheral V1domain possesses the nucleotide binding sites, and the integral V0 domain is responsible for proton translocation across the membrane. The V-ATPases resemble the F-ATPases from mitochondria, chloroplasts, and bacteria (9Weber J. Senior A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1319: 19-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar, 10Fillingame R.H. J. Exp. Biol. 1997; 200: 217-224Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Cross R.L. Duncan T.M. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1996; 28: 403-408Crossref PubMed Scopus (67) Google Scholar, 12Pedersen P.L. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1996; 28: 389-395Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 13Capaldi R.A. Aggeler R. Wilkens S. Gerhard G. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1996; 28: 397-401Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar, 14Futai M. Omote H. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1996; 28: 409-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar, 15Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-2150Crossref PubMed Scopus (913) Google Scholar), both in overall structure and in sequence homology between individual subunits. The A and B subunits of the V-ATPases and the α and β subunits of F1 are all derived from a common ancestral nucleotide-binding protein (16Bowman E.J. Tenney K. Bowman B.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 13994-14001Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 17Zimniak L. Dittrich P. Gogarten J.P. Kibak H. Taiz L. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 9102-9112Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), whereas the c subunit of the V-ATPases appears to have arisen by a gene duplication and fusion of the gene encoding the corresponding c subunit of F0 (18Mandel M. Moriyama Y. Hulmes J.D. Pan Y.-C.E. Nelson H. Nelson N. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 5521-5524Crossref PubMed Scopus (238) Google Scholar). Also, V- and F-type ATPases may share some similarities in their catalytic cycle. For example, cooperative interaction between the nucleotide binding sites has been demonstrated for the V-ATPase (19Uchida E. Ohsumi J. Anraku Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 45-51Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 20Kasho V.N. Boyer P.D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 8708-8711Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar, 21Zhang J. Vasilyeva E. Feng Y. Forgac M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 15494-15500Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 22Vasilyeva E. Forgac M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 12775-12782Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), as well as for the F-ATPase (9Weber J. Senior A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1319: 19-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar).On the other hand, there are many differences between the F- and V-type ATPases, including their normal physiological functions. The primary function of F-ATPases (more properly termed ATP synthases) is ATP synthesis using the energy of the proton electrochemical gradient generated by electron transport during respiration (9Weber J. Senior A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1319: 19-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar, 10Fillingame R.H. J. Exp. Biol. 1997; 200: 217-224Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Cross R.L. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-2150Crossref PubMed Scopus (913) Google Scholar). In contrast, the V-ATPases function principally as ATP-dependent proton pumps to acidify intracellular compartments or in proton transport across the plasma membrane (1Stevens T.H. Forgac M. Annu. Siebers A. Altendorf K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 7972-7976Crossref PubMed Scopus (1587) Google Scholar, 25Drose S. Bindseil K.U. Bowman E.J. Siebers A. Zeeck A. Altendorf K. Sodium azide at concentrations below 1 mmhas also been shown to inhibit the F-ATPases, but only in the direction of ATP hydrolysis, not in the direction of ATP synthesis (26Robertson H.E. Boyer P.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1955; 214: 295-305Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 27Kobayashi H. Maeda M. Anraku Y. J. Biochem. 1977; 81: 1071-1077Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). It is widely accepted that the V-ATPases are insensitive to azide, but this conclusion is based upon studies of ATP hydrolysis (28Kakinuma Y. Ohsumi Y. Anraku Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 10859-10863Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29Uchida E. Ohsumi Y. Anraku Y. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 157: 544-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 30Bowman E.J. Biol. Chem. 1982; 258: 4059-4062Abstract Full Text PDF Google Scholar, 32Xie X.-S. Stone D.K. Racker E. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 157: 634-646Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar, 33David P. Baron R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30158-30163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 34Xie X.-S. Stone D.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 9859-9867Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar).Although there has been extensive kinetic characterization of the F-ATPases, there is relatively little information concerning the kinetics and regulation of the V-ATPases. There is considerable evidence that cells maintain different intracellular compartments at different pH values (1Stevens T.H. Forgac M. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1997; 13: 779-808Crossref PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 2Bowman B.J. Vazquez-Laslop N. Bowman E.J. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 361-370Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 3Kibak H. Taiz L. Starke T. Bernasconi P. Gogarten J.P. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 415-424Crossref PubMed Scopus (57) Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 407-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 5Anraku Y. Umemoto N. Hirata R. Ohya Y. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 395-405Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar, 6Kane P.M. Stevens T.H. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 383-394Crossref Scopus (56) Google Scholar, 7Sze H. Ward J.M. Lai S. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 371-382Crossref Scopus (179) Google Scholar, 8Gluck S.L. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 351-360Crossref Scopus (53) Google Scholar), but the mechanisms employed to accomplish this remain uncertain. A change in coupling efficiency between proton transport and ATP hydrolysis has been proposed as one potential regulatory mechanism (1Stevens T.H. Forgac M. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1997; 13: 779-808Crossref PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 407-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar, 8Gluck S.L. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 21: 351-360Crossref Scopus (53) Google Scholar), but the intracellular signals that might control coupling remain uncertain.We report here the modulation of V-ATPase activity by ADP and azide. ADP is shown to form an inactive complex with the V-ATPase in the presence of Mg2+, which is only slowly reactivated upon addition of ATP. This effect is independent of its action as a competitive inhibitor. Unlike the case of the F-ATPases, azide does not stabilize the ADP-inactivated state of the V-ATPase. Instead, azide is shown to inhibit proton transport without affecting ATP hydrolysis. This effect does not appear to be due to azide acting as a proton ionophore. Rather, azide may be having a direct effect on the V-ATPase. The possible significance of these effects of ADP and azide on V-ATPase activity are discussed below.DISCUSSIONIn this work, we observed that the V-ATPase from clathrin-coated vesicles is subject to two different types of inhibition by ADP. The first is competitive inhibition with respect to ATP, with aK i for ADP of 11 μm. The other occurs after preincubation of the V-ATPase in the presence of ADP and Mg2+, which results in inhibition of the initial rate of proton transport followed by reactivation of the enzyme over the course of several minutes following addition of ATP. The second effect was observed at ADP concentrations as low as 0.1–0.2 μm, suggesting the involvement of a high affinity site distinct from that involved in competitive inhibition.Competitive inhibition of the V-ATPases of kidney and osteoclasts by ADP has previously been reported with K i values of 37 and 17 μm, respectively (33David P. Baron R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 30158-30163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), whereas ADP was reported to be a noncompetitive inhibitor of the yeast V-ATPase (5Anraku Y. Umemoto N. Hirata R. Ohya Y. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 395-405Crossref PubMed Scopus (63) Google Scholar), although in neither case were effects on proton transport evaluated. Allosteric inhibition by ADP of ATP hydrolysis was reported for the chromaffin granule V-ATPase (44Moriyama J. Nelson N. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 14723-14729Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), but this effect required much higher concentrations of ADP (100 μm). Similarly, ADP was shown to increase the cooperativity of ATP binding to the chromaffin granule V-ATPase, but the concentrations of ADP required were rather high (25–200 μm), and only steady state analysis was carried out, so that no effects of preincubation with ADP and Mg2+were investigated (45Webster L.C. Perez-Castineira J.R. Atkins G.L. Apps D.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 232: 586-595Crossref PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar). Binding of [3H]ADP to a high affinity site (K d = ∼70 nm) were observed for the chromaffin granule V-ATPase (46Webster L.C. Apps D.K. Eur. J. Biochem. 1996; 240: 156-164Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar), but the effect of occupancy at this site on activity was not reported. Finally, sulfite has been suggested to activate the V-ATPase of yeast by causing release of inhibitory ADP that accumulates at high ATP concentrations during the initial phase of the reaction (47Kibak H. Van Eeckhout D. Cutler T. Taiz S.L. Taiz L. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23325-23333Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), but no direct interaction of the V-ATPase with ADP was investigated in this study. Our study thus represents the first direct demonstration that ADP (at submicromolar concentrations) in the presence of Mg2+ is able to stabilize an inhibited state of the enzyme, which is only slowly activated on addition of ATP.The observed inhibitory effect of ADP on the V-ATPase is similar to that described for the F-ATPase. Thus, preincubation of the F-ATPase with ADP and Mg2+ results in a lag phase in ATP hydrolysis that has been interpreted as indicating the formation of an inhibited complex between the F-ATPase and ADP bound with high affinity at a catalytic site (42Vasilyeva E.A. Minkov I.B. Fitin A.F. Vinogradov A.D. Biochem. J. 1982; 202: 1-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar, 48Feldman R.I. Boyer P.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 13088-13094Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 49Milgrom Y.M. Cross R.L. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23179-23185Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The same complex is believed to be formed during ATP hydrolysis as a transient intermediate during turnover (42Vasilyeva E.A. Minkov I.B. Fitin A.F. Vinogradov A.D. Biochem. J. 1982; 202: 1-14Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). ADP bound to the noncatalytic sites of the F-ATPase has also been reported to cause hysteretic inhibition of activity (50Jault J.-M. Allison W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 319-325Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Azide has been shown to inhibit the F-ATPase by stabilization of the ADP-inactivated complex (43Vasilyeva E.A. Minkov I.B. Fitin A.F. Vinogradov A.D. Biochem. J. 1982; 202: 15-23Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar, 51Murataliev M. Milgrom Y. Boyer P. Biochemistry. 1991; 30: 8305-8310Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar, 52Muneyuki E. Makino M. Kamata H. Kagawa Y. Yoshida M. Hirata H. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1144: 62-68Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Interestingly, ATP synthesis is much less sensitive to azide inhibition than ATPase activity (26Robertson H.E. Boyer P.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1955; 214: 295-305Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar,27Kobayashi H. Maeda M. Anraku Y. J. Biochem. 1977; 81: 1071-1077Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar).Because of the similar inhibitory effects of ADP on the V and F-ATPases, we decided to test the effects of azide on V-ATPase activity. Azide has previously been reported to not inhibit V-ATPase activity, but the principal assay used in these studies was ATP hydrolysis (28Kakinuma Y. Ohsumi Y. Anraku Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1981; 256: 10859-10863Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 29Uchida E. Ohsumi Y. Anraku Y. Methods Enzymol. 1988; 157: 544-561Crossref PubMed Scopus (33) Google Scholar, 30Bowman E.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 15238-15244Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We therefore tested the effects of azide on ATP-dependent proton transport by the V-ATPase. We observed that azide does inhibit proton transport by the V-ATPase, with 50% inhibition observed at 200–400 μm. In agreement with previous observations, however, azide does not have a measurable effect on ATP hydrolysis.These results suggest that azide acts to functionally uncouple ATP hydrolysis and proton transport by the V-ATPase. One possible mechanism by which this might occur is if azide can act as a proton ionophore. We therefore tested the ability of azide to act as a proton ionophore in the presence of both an interior positive and an interior negative membrane potential. In neither case did we observe any increase in passive proton conductance in the presence of azide. This suggests that azide does not inhibit proton transport by the V-ATPase by simply dissipating the proton gradient generated, although this possibility is difficult to rule out with certainty.A second possibility is that azide specifically uncouples proton transport from ATP hydrolysis by the V-ATPase. In fact, several lines of evidence suggest that the V-ATPase is poised to change the efficiency of coupling between hydrolysis and transport. Thus, mild proteolysis results in a complete loss of proton transport under conditions where only 50% of the ATP hydrolysis is lost (53Adachi I. Arai H. Pimental R. Forgac M. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 960-966Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). High concentrations of ATP (54Arai H. Pink S. Forgac M. Biochemistry. 1989; 28: 3075-3082Crossref PubMed Scopus (78) Google Scholar), high concentrations of sulfite (47Kibak H. Van Eeckhout D. Cutler T. Taiz S.L. Taiz L. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 23325-23333Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), and the presence of detergent (55Arai H. Berne M. Forgac M. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 11006-11011Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) have also been suggested to alter the efficiency of coupling between ATP hydrolysis and proton transport. In fact, a “slip” mechanism has been proposed as a means of regulating vacuolar acidification in vivo (1Stevens T.H. Forgac M. Annu. Rev. Cell Dev. Biol. 1997; 13: 779-808Crossref PubMed Scopus (520) Google Scholar, 4Nelson N. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1992; 24: 407-414Crossref PubMed Scopus (70) Google Scholar), although the nature of the cellular factors controlling coupling efficiency remains uncertain. Azide is not simply causing a complete uncoupling of ATP hydrolysis from proton transport, however, because in this case, azide would be expected to increase ATP hydrolysis by the reconstituted V-ATPase (as is observed on addition of CCCP). No such increase in ATP hydrolysis is observed on addition of azide. Rather, azide appears to reduce the coupling efficiency in such a way that proton transport is decreased without stimulation or inhibition of ATP hydrolysis.An alternative possible explanation for the observed results is that azide inhibits only tightly coupled V-ATPase after formation of a pH gradient. In the case of proton transport, this would explain why azide did not inhibit the initial rate of proton transport but did inhibit total acidification, because no pH gradient would be present prior to the addition of ATP. In addition, the ATP hydrolysis observed in the absence of CCCP may represent V-ATPase that is not tightly coupled (and hence not susceptible to inhibition by azide), whereas the ATP hydrolysis observed in the presence of CCCP is obviously uncoupled (and hence not inhibited). Such a mechanism is intriguing because it suggests the possibility that the proton gradient itself may be feeding back on the V-ATPase cycle in such a way that the enzyme activity can be inhibited in response to the pH gradient generated.The connection between the effects of ADP and azide on V-ATPase activity is uncertain. Although the enzyme is still able to form an inactive complex with ADP and Mg2+ in the presence of azide, the kinetics of reactivation after addition of ATP are not greatly different in the presence or absence of azide, suggesting that azide is not stabilizing the ADP-inactivated state of the enzyme, as proposed for the F-ATPases.The nature of the high affinity ADP site responsible for inhibition (catalytic or regulatory), the role of Mg2+ and the molecular basis for the azide sensitivity of the V-ATPase remain to be determined. It has previously been shown that both rapidly and slowly exchangeable nucleotide binding sites can be detected on the V-ATPase (21Zhang J. Vasilyeva E. Feng Y. Forgac M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 15494-15500Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar, 22Vasilyeva E. Forgac M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 12775-12782Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar), and it is possible that ADP causes this slowly reversible inactivation by binding to the slowly exchangeable site. Although the V-ATPase is unlikely to be exposed to ADP in the absence of ATP under intracellular conditions, the existence of such a slowly reversible inactive state of the enzyme may be of relevance to regulation of vacuolar acidification in vivo. In particular, additional information will be required concerning the possible cellular factors influencing the equilibrium between the active and ADP-inhibited states. V-ATPases are composed of two functional domains: the peripheral V1domain possesses the nucleotide binding sites, and the integral V0 domain is responsible for proton translocation across the membrane. The V-ATPases resemble the F-ATPases from mitochondria, chloroplasts, and bacteria (9Weber J. Senior A. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1319: 19-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar, 10Fillingame R.H. J. Exp. Biol. 1997; 200: 217-224Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 11Cross R.L. Duncan T.M. J. Bioenerg. The conformation and internal dynamics of a bioactive cyclic peptide, N-acetyl-YCTDEKQCY, derived from the C-D loop of β-nerve growth factor (β-NGF) were analyzed by solution NMR spectroscopy. NMR experimental data were used to calculate an ensemble of peptide structures. All of the structures had a β-turn at residues Asp4–Gln7 but could be divided into two families according the presence or absence of a hydrogen bond at Gln7. Comparison of the calculated structures with the corresponding C-D loops from the x-ray structures of the NGF revealed striking similarity. The orientation of Glu5, Lys6, and Gln7 side chains in the NGF mimetic was very similar to the C-D loop of NGF. These residues are known to participate in interactions with the TrkA receptor. Relaxation measurements of the peptidomimetic α-carbons at 13C natural abundance and calculated dynamic parameters suggest that the loop region of peptide is well structured but that residues Thr3, Asp4, Glu5, and Lys6 undergo slow conformational exchange. These results suggest that conformational similarity and possibly peptide dynamics are responsible for the bioactivity of the peptide. Nerve growth factor (NGF)1 is a member of the neurotrophin family of polypeptide growth factors. NGF promotes the growth and survival of sympathetic, trigeminal, dorsal root ganglia neurons and cholinergic neurons of the basal forebrain. Two cell surface neurotrophin receptors have been characterized: the low affinity p75 receptor (K D ∼10−9m), which is common to all members of the neurotrophin family (1Radeke M.J. Misko T.P. Hsu C. Herzenberg L.A. Shooter E.M. Nature. 1987; 325: 593-597Crossref PubMed Scopus (720) Google Scholar, 2Johnson D. Lanahan A. Buck C.R. Sehgal A. Morgan C. Mercer E. Bothwell M. Chao M. Martin-Zanca D. Kaplan D.R. Parada L.F. Chao M.V. Nature. 1991; 350: 678-683Crossref PubMed Scopus (1016) Google Scholar, 5Kaplan D.R. Hampstead B.L. Martin-Zanca D. Chao M.V. Parada L.F. The neurotrophin protomers have the same overall topology of seven β-strands connected by three disulfide bridges arranged in a cysteine knot motif. Comparison of the primary sequence of different neurotrophins shows clusters of high homology (>50% identity) and high diversity. The hypervariable domains occur in the exposed β-loops (residues 29–35, 43–48, and 92–98), in an exposed reverse turn (residues 59–66), in a solvent-exposed β-strand (residues 79–89), and at both N and C termini.
